cluster_classes.class_description: Narrative stories that depict threats and negative consequences to warn audiences about risks in the world, especially through urban legend motifs.
cluster_classes.class_group: Cautionary Urban Legends – Child Luring Scenarios
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: cautionary tales and dangers that lurk in the world around them

members.entity_description: Stories intended to warn audiences about risks, dangers, or undesirable behaviors, often by depicting negative consequences.
Various threats, harms, or risks portrayed as lurking in the world in cautionary urban legends.

cluster_classes.class_description: Roles in cautionary urban legends where unfamiliar adults act as potential predators and children are portrayed as vulnerable targets.
cluster_classes.class_group: Cautionary Urban Legends – Child Luring Scenarios
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: unfamiliar adults depicted as potential predators who attempt to lure children

members.entity_description: Unfamiliar adults depicted as potential predators who attempt to lure children in urban legend stories.
Young people portrayed as vulnerable targets of predatory strangers in cautionary urban legends.

cluster_classes.class_description: Family members or close associates that communities aim to protect by sharing urban legends and related cautionary stories.
cluster_classes.class_group: Urban Legend Social Actors and Groups
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: communities can come together to protect themselves and their loved ones from perceived threats

members.entity_description: Family members or close associates that communities aim to protect by sharing legends.

cluster_classes.class_label: Bait Objects in Child-Luring Urban Legends
cluster_classes.class_description: Tempting objects (such as candy) used by predators as bait to lure children in cautionary urban legend narratives.
cluster_classes.class_group: Cautionary Urban Legends – Child Luring Scenarios
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Stories of strangers luring children with candy ... warn listeners about the dangers

members.entity_description: Sweets used as bait by strangers in cautionary tales about child luring.

cluster_classes.class_description: Listeners and audiences who receive the implied warnings and moral lessons from cautionary urban legend stories.
cluster_classes.class_group: Cautionary Urban Legends – Child Luring Scenarios
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Stories of strangers luring children with candy ... warn listeners about the dangers

members.entity_description: People who hear these urban legends and receive the implied warnings about danger.

args.name: Child Victims in Cautionary Urban Legends
args.description: Children portrayed as vulnerable targets or victims in cautionary urban legend narratives, particularly in child-luring scenarios.
args.justification: The current class 'Predatory Strangers and Child Victims' conflates two distinct narrative roles (predators and victims); a separate class for child victims improves role-level clarity while preserving the existing schema structure.
The entity 'children' is specifically the victim role and belongs in the newly created 'Child Victims in Cautionary Urban Legends' class rather than a mixed predator/victim class.

args.new_name: Predatory Strangers in Cautionary Urban Legends
args.new_description: Unfamiliar adults depicted as potential predators who attempt to lure or harm children in cautionary urban legend narratives.
args.justification: After moving the victim role to its own class, this class should be narrowed to the predator role and aligned under a unified 'Cautionary Urban Legends' class group shared across related narrative elements.

The new child-victim role class belongs in the same overarching domain as the other cautionary-legend narrative roles and objects, so it should share the unified 'Cautionary Urban Legends' class group.

This class describes the cautionary urban legend stories and the dangers they depict; aligning it to the broader 'Cautionary Urban Legends' class group connects it coherently with the related roles and objects.

Loved ones as protected individuals are clearly part of the same cautionary urban-legend ecosystem as the predators, victims, and audiences; moving from the narrower 'Urban Legend Social Actors and Groups' to the unified 'Cautionary Urban Legends' class group makes cross-class relationships clearer.
Bait objects like candy are specific narrative elements within the same cautionary urban legend domain, so their class group should be harmonized with the other related legend classes.

The audience/listeners role is part of the same cautionary urban legend system as the narratives, predators, victims, bait objects, and protected loved ones; placing it under the unified 'Cautionary Urban Legends' class group connects all these interdependent roles.

executed_decisions.justification: The current class 'Predatory Strangers and Child Victims' conflates two distinct narrative roles (predators and victims); a separate class for child victims improves role-level clarity while preserving the existing schema structure.
